content:
Diagnosis:	Metastatic adenocarcinoma of lung (left hilar primary)
	Diagnosed January 2024
	T2bN2M1 with pleural and bone metastases
	EGFR L861Q mutation positive, ALK negative

[redacted name] was reviewed today in the thoracic oncology clinic. She has been receiving first-line osimertinib 80mg daily since 15/1/24 for EGFR-mutant metastatic lung adenocarcinoma. Her initial presentation included significant left-sided chest pain and dyspnoea, which showed good improvement with treatment initiation.

Unfortunately, her most recent CT scan on 15/4/24 shows evidence of disease progression with increasing size of the primary lesion (now 4.8cm from 3.2cm) and new pleural nodularity, despite initial disease stability at the 6-week assessment. Her bone metastases remain stable. She has also noted increasing breathlessness over the past 3 weeks, now requiring 2L/min oxygen at rest, and her performance status has declined from 1 to 2.

Given this evidence of disease progression on first-line osimertinib, we have discussed second-line treatment options. Her case was reviewed at yesterday's Lung MDT where platinum-based chemotherapy was recommended. I have had a detailed discussion with [redacted name] regarding carboplatin/pemetrexed chemotherapy, including the expected side effects and likelihood of response. She understands this represents a change in treatment intent but remains keen to pursue active treatment.

On examination today, she has reduced breath sounds at the left base with dullness to percussion. Oxygen saturations are 94% on 2L/min oxygen. Blood results show stable renal function and adequate bone marrow reserve for chemotherapy.

Plan:
- Discontinue osimertinib
- Commence carboplatin AUC5 and pemetrexed 500mg/m2 q21 days
- Baseline CT scan completed today
- Review in 3 weeks with cycle 1 chemotherapy
- Arrange urgent pleural team review for consideration of pleural intervention if symptoms worsen
- Continue current analgesia and oxygen support
